questions.text: After administering spinal anaesthesia to a patient, he is not able to lift the extended leg, but can flex his knees and move his ankle joint. Which of the following modified Bromage scores does he fall into at present?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Inability to raise the extended leg, but able to move the knees and ankle joint, comes under Score 1 in Modified Bromage Scale.
  • The Modified Bromage Scale is a clinical tool used to assess motor block following neuraxial anaesthesia (such as spinal or epidural anaesthesia).
  • It helps anesthesiologists determine the degree of lower limb motor impairment, typically after administration of local anaesthetics in the subarachnoid or epidural space.
  • Used in obstetrics, orthopaedics, and general surgery to track motor recovery or progression.
  • Helps assess whether a patient is safe to ambulate after regional anaesthesia.
  • Also used to monitor for excessive spread of local anaesthetic or complications like high spinal block.

questions.text: In a pediatric patient, while identifying landmarks for a caudal epidural block, the equilateral triangle is formed by the two posterior superior iliac spines and which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The equilateral triangle is formed by the two posterior superior iliac spines and sacral hiatus in caudal epidural block.

Site of Caudal Block:

  • Landmark-based or ultrasound-guided block performed at the sacral hiatus
  • The sacral hiatus is formed by unfused laminae of S4 and S5
  • Located between the sacral cornua, just above the coccyx
  • Needle/catheter passes through the sacrococcyx ligament into the caudal epidural space
  • The posterior superior iliac spines (PSIS) and the sacral hiatus form an equilateral triangle, useful for surface landmark identification.

Indications:

  • Pediatric surgeries below the umbilicus (e.g., hernia repair, circumcision, hypospadias)
  • Perineal, rectal, and lower limb surgeries
  • Postoperative analgesia in children
  • Can also be used in selected adult cases, though less common

Disadvantages / Complications:

  • Inadvertent intravascular or intrathecal injection
  • Infection or abscess formation
  • Hematoma
  • Drug toxicity (especially in paediatrics if dosing is not weight-adjusted)
  • Incomplete or failed block (common with incorrect landmark identification)
  • Dural puncture and potential for post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) in older children or adults

questions.text: Structures encountered while traversing the needle from skin to subarachnoid space are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The posterior longitudinal ligament lies anterior to the meninges and hence is not pierced.

questions.text: The line connecting the highest points of the iliac crests, often palpated during spinal anaesthesia, is known as Tuffier's line. Through which vertebral level does Tuffier's line typically pass in adults?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Tuffier's line usually crosses either the body of L4 or the L4-L5 interspace.
  • One of the major characteristics of the child for the central blocks is a line connecting the two iliac crests - the Tuffier line.
  • This line joining the two iliac crests is proportionally smaller in young children and crosses the spinous process line at the L5 to S1 level in infants up to 1 year of age instead of at L4 to L5 as in older children and adults.
  • Bending the spine (as for performing an epidural block) does change the level at which the Tuffier line crosses the spine in 58.3% of patients.
  • Spinous processes are usually palpable and help to define the midline.
  • Counting spinous processes up or down from these reference points identifies other spinal levels.

questions.text: A spinal neuraxial anaesthetic was given 20 minutes earlier to a 28-year-old G3P2 patient scheduled for a repeat caesarean section. Alcohol swab exam revealed that she has lost temperature sensation up to the T2 level. At what level do you anticipate the block will reach to provide adequate pain control?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The peritoneum (especially the upper part) receives innervation up to T4. Surgical manipulation can cause referred pain if higher dermatomes aren't anaesthetised. So, at T4 level, the block will provide adequate pain control.
  • The uterus is innervated by T10-L1,
  • A manifestation of relative sensitivity or susceptibility of nerve fibres to the effects of local anaesthetics is the observed differences in the peak block height (highest or most cephalad level of anaesthesia) according to each sensory modality, which is termed differential sensory blockade.
  • For example, the level of anaesthesia to cold sensation(also an approximate level of sympathetic blockade) is most cephalad and is on average one to two spinal segments higher than the level of pinprick anaesthesia, which in turn is one to two segments higher than the level of touch anaesthesia.
  • In this spinal block, the alcohol swab tested the level of sensory/sympathetic blockade.

choices.text: Adult spinal cord ends at L2
Spinal cord in children ends at L3
The dural sac and subarachnoid space in adults end at S1
The dural sac and subarachnoid space in children end at S2

questions.text: The correct statement for human neuraxial anatomy is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The spinal cord typically ends around L1 in adults and around L3 in children. (Option A and B)
  • This is the reason why neuraxial blocks are performed below these levels and carry a lower risk of direct spinal cord injury.

The dural sac and subarachnoid spaces end at S2 in adults and S3 in children. (Option C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Factors influencing the level of spinal anaesthesia achieved include all of the following, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The following table shows the factors affecting the local anaesthetic distribution and block height, and Gender does not play a role in the level of spinal anaesthesia.

questions.text: During performance of lumbar epidural anaesthesia for labour analgesia, you experience free-flowing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the advancing 17-G Tuohy epidural needle. The epidural needle is removed, and a second attempt is successfully performed with an epidural catheter placed at a different level. Which of the following would you not recommend for the patient to practice in the next 72 hours?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In patients who may experience a "wet tap" during placement of an epidural, conservative therapy should include bed rest and plenty of fluid intake, including caffeine.
  • So, fluid restriction should not be recommended.
  • Food diet low in fiber and stool softeners is encouraged to prevent straining.
  • Leakage of CSF can lead to a reduction in intracranial pressure, and post-dural puncture headache chances are high since the epidural needle (Tuohy needle) is a 16/18 G needle.
  • Larger diameter needles (i.e., lower gauge numbers) → more CSF leak → higher risk of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH)
  • Smaller diameter needles (i.e., higher gauge numbers) → less CSF leak → lower risk of PDPH

choices.text: Adult patient who does not give consent for the procedure
Pediatric patient who is under sedation
Patient who has a subdural hematoma with a midline shift

questions.text: Which of the following patients is not contraindicated to receive central neuraxial blockade from among the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neuraxial blockade with general anaesthesia or sedation is commonly used in the pediatric age group. However, unsedated young children may not be suitable for pure regional techniques.

Contraindications to Neuraxial Blockade

Absolute

  • Infection at the site of injection
  • Lack of consent
  • Coagulopathy or other bleeding diathesis (Option B)
  • Severe hypovolemia
  • Increased intracranial pressure (Option D)

Relative

  • Sepsis
  • Uncooperative patient (Option A)
  • Preexisting neurological deficits
  • Demyelinating lesions
  • Stenotic valvular heart lesions
  • Left ventricular outflow obstruction (hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy)
  • Severe spinal deformity

Controversial

  • Prior back surgery at the site of injection
  • Complicated surgery
  • Prolonged operation
  • Major blood loss
  • Manoeuvres that compromise respiration

questions.text: Enoxaparin dose twice daily for thromboprophylaxis should be started how many hours after surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to ASRA guidelines, for twice-daily dosing (i.e., with enoxaparin), administer the first dose no earlier than 24 hours postoperatively, regardless of anaesthetic technique, and only in the presence of adequate hemostasis.

Reference: ASRA Guidelines

questions.text: If you administer spinal anaesthesia with all three spinal needles given in the image below, which one will provide you the most vigorous CSF flow?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given image,

A- Quincke needle

B- Whitacre needle

C- Sprotte needle

choices.text: Breakdown of local anaesthetics by enzymes

questions.text: Three hours after giving spinal anaesthesia, the patient started to have sensations. Regression of the effect of spinal anaesthesia occurs due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Regression of neural blockade results from a decline in the CSF drug concentration, which in turn is caused by non-neural tissue uptake and, most importantly, vascular absorption.
  • No drug metabolism takes place in the CSF. The rate of elimination is also dependent on the distribution of local anaesthetics; a greater spread will expose the drug to a larger area for vascular absorption and thus a shorter duration of action.

Explanation of other options:

Diffusion into the spinal cord (Option A): The drug is confined to the subarachnoid space and does not significantly redistribute into the epidural space.

Systemic metabolism (Option B): Local anaesthetics are eventually metabolised in the liver (amide group) or plasma (ester group), but this is not the main mechanism for regression of spinal anaesthesia.

Breakdown by enzymes (Option D): Spinal drugs are not broken down by enzymes in the CSF. Unlike ester-type drugs (which are broken down in plasma), the enzymatic breakdown plays no major role in CSF drug clearance.
